lead_paragraph: Textbook publishers have embraced spelling and accent changes approved in 1990, and French-speaking traditionalists are venting anger at a perceived attack on culture and history.

byline.contributor: Aurelien Breeden contributed reporting from Aix-en-Provence, France.

headline.print_headline: In France, Tempers Flare Over Spelling
headline.main: French Spelling Changes, 26 Years in the Making, Cause a Fracas

snippet: Textbook publishers have embraced spelling and accent changes approved in 1990, and French-speaking traditionalists are venting anger at a perceived attack on culture and history.
abstract: Plans by French language institute Academie Francaise to cut circumflex accent from French textbooks and make changes to some 2,400 French words have prompted backlash from teachers and public.
